studyName: Mafia Archipelago, Tanzania 17th and 20th Century Diploastrea Coral d18O

investigators: Damassa, T.D.; Cole, J.E.; Barnett, H.R.; Ault, T.R.; McClanahan, T.R.
studyNotes:
This dataset includes d18O values and anomalies from a coral 
that grew in the tropical western Indian Ocean, in Tanzania's 
Mafia archipelago. Data span the 20th century at monthly 
resolution and the interval of 1622-1721 at bimonthly resolution. 
Anomalies were calculated by subtracting the mean value for the 
1 or 2 month period as appropriate for dataset resolution. 
These data originate from a single colony of Diploastrea heliopora 
cored in July 2000 at Fungu Mrima Reef in the Mafia Archipelago 
of Tanzania. We slabbed and X-rayed the core and characterized 
the growth geometry using SEM. We sampled the columella portion 
of the skeleton at 0.25 mm (for the 20th-century) and 0.5 mm 
(for the 17th century) depth intervals using a diamond-encrusted 
drill bit. We assigned ages to the samples based on density 
banding and isotopic seasonality, assuming d18O maxima fell 
in August (the coldest month). We estimate the age uncertainty 
for the 20th century interval as ~±1yr and for the older interval 
at ~±5yr. 
Fungu Mrima Reef, Mafia Archipelago, Tanzania

publication.title: Enhanced multidecadal climate variability in the 17th century  from coral isotope records in the western Indian Ocean
publication.citation:
Damassa, T.D., J.E. Cole, H.R. Barnett, T.R. Ault, 
and T.R. McClanahan. 2006. 
Enhanced multidecadal climate variability in the 17th century 
from coral isotope records in the western Indian Ocean. 
Paleoceanography, 21, PA2016, doi: 10.1029/2005PA001217
publication.abstract:
The slowly growing coral Diploastrea heliopora affords a novel 
opportunity to obtain multicentury records of paleoclimate, 
including details of the interannual rhythms associated with 
the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) system. We examine 
climate variability in an ENSO-teleconnected region using 
new oxygen isotope records from D. heliopora, spanning most 
of the twentieth (1896-1998) and seventeenth (1622-1722) 
centuries, from the Mafia archipelago, Tanzania. The modern 
record demonstrates coherency with relevant instrumental 
and proxy time series, documents twentieth century warming, 
and displays significant power at ENSO periodicities. 
The seventeenth century record lacks any trend, exhibits 
interannual variance comparable to the modern record, 
and displays a pronounced interdecadal signal not evident 
in the twentieth century that correlates with other tropical 
and hemispheric climate records. We find no clear evidence 
of solar irradiance influence on interannual variability 
in the western Indian Ocean during these intervals, 
although the mean sea surface temperature appears to 
vary inversely with insolation.
